metadata.source: NASA EONET, EFFIS, Turkish Forestry Department, Perplexity Research
metadata.description: Fire/wildfire events in Turkey 1-2 months before the February 6, 2023 earthquake

seasonal_context.explanation: December through February is the OFF-SEASON for wildfires in Turkey
seasonal_context.winter_fire_risk: Substantially reduced due to cooler temperatures, increased precipitation, lower atmospheric aridity

fire_statistics_2023.note: 75.3% of fires affected less than 1 hectare

notes: Winter (Dec-Feb) is the lowest fire-risk period in Turkey's annual cycle
No major documented wildfires occurred in Turkey during this specific period
This is NOT a data gap - it reflects the seasonal reality of low fire activity
Historical 89% of Turkish fires are human-caused, but winter conditions suppress ignitions
Mediterranean and Aegean coastal regions (Hatay, Antalya, Muğla, İzmir) would be most vulnerable if fires occurred
The February 6, 2023 earthquake would later shift all emergency resources to earthquake response

nasa_firms_api.description: NASA FIRMS provides satellite-detected thermal anomalies for Turkey
nasa_firms_api.note: Requires free API key from https://firms.modaps.eosdis.nasa.gov/api/
nasa_firms_api.data_availability: Historical data available but winter period shows minimal thermal anomalies

vulnerable_regions.name: Hatay Province
vulnerable_regions.note: Would be devastated by February 6, 2023 earthquake

vulnerable_regions.name: Antalya Province
vulnerable_regions.historical: 2021 Manavgat wildfire was one of largest in Turkish history (July-August)

vulnerable_regions.name: Muğla Province
vulnerable_regions.historical: Suffered substantial forest losses in 2021 summer fires

fire_causes_turkey.power_infrastructure: 17-27% of burned areas in 2020-2022 from electrical infrastructure fires

note: The absence of fire events is expected and accurate for this winter period. Winter conditions in Turkey suppress fire ignition and spread.
